hero.originalTitle: At 67,800-years-old, These Handprints Just Discovered in Indonesia Are Oldest Example of Rock Art
hero.headline: Ancient Artists Left Their Mark 67,800 Years Ago (And We're Still Impressed)
hero.excerpt: Stylized handprints discovered in a limestone cave in Indonesia have broken the world record for oldest-known rock art at 67,800 years old. The discovery provides direct evidence that humans have been crossing seas intentionally for nearly 70,000 years.
hero.author: Flora Fauna

fullContent.lead: Look, we're a toilet paper company writing about ancient cave art, so we're definitely outside our wheelhouse here. But sometimes the best news comes from the most unexpected places – like a limestone cave in Indonesia where researchers just discovered handprints that are making archaeologists do a happy dance.
body: These aren't just any handprints, mind you. We're talking about stylized handprints that clock in at a whopping 67,800 years old, officially breaking the world record for oldest-known rock art. That's so old it makes your great-great-great... (insert about 2,700 more 'greats') grandmother look practically modern.

But here's where it gets really fascinating: this discovery isn't just about ancient humans having an artistic moment. According to the report, these handprints provide direct evidence that humans have been intentionally crossing seas for nearly 70,000 years. Think about that for a second – while we stress about booking the right airline seat, our ancestors were confidently island-hopping across open water with Stone Age technology.

There's something beautifully human about these handprints, isn't there? Tens of thousands of years ago, someone pressed their hand against a cave wall and thought, 'I was here.' It's the same impulse that makes us carve initials in trees or post vacation photos – that fundamental desire to leave a mark, to say we existed. Only their Instagram story lasted just a tiny bit longer than ours.

featured.headline: Living Drug Revolution: Gene Therapy Beats 'Untreatable' Blood Cancer
featured.excerpt: Gene therapy that transforms white blood cells into a disease-fighting "living drug" has successfully reversed previously untreatable blood cancers. The breakthrough treatment offers new hope for patients who had run out of options.
featured.author: Liv Long

fullContent.lead: Look, we usually stick to what we know best—toilet paper and terrible puns—but sometimes science drops news so good we can't help but share it. Scientists have figured out how to turn patients' own white blood cells into a 'living drug' that fights blood cancers previously considered untreatable. And honestly? That's pretty incredible.
body: According to the report, this breakthrough gene therapy works by transforming white blood cells into disease-fighting powerhouses. We're not scientists (reminder: we make TP), but the concept is genuinely mind-blowing—taking cells from a patient's own body and essentially reprogramming them to become cancer fighters.

What makes this particularly exciting is that the therapy has successfully reversed blood cancers that doctors had previously labeled as untreatable. For patients who had exhausted all other treatment options, this represents something that seemed impossible just a short while ago: genuine hope.

The treatment is being called a 'living drug,' which sounds like something straight out of science fiction but is apparently very real science fact. It's one of those moments that reminds us why we love sharing positive news—sometimes the world surprises us with solutions that seemed impossible just yesterday.

featured.originalTitle: Nebraska Woman Learns to Row, Then Becomes First Female to Cross the Atlantic Alone in 3,000 Mile Race
featured.headline: From Nebraska Landlubber to Atlantic Ocean Champion in Record Time
featured.excerpt: Taryn Smith, 25, learned to row after reading about an all-female rowing team's world record. She has now become the first female to cross the Atlantic alone in a 3,000-mile race, fulfilling her ocean dreams despite starting from landlocked Nebraska.
featured.author: Pat Ontheback

fullContent.lead: Look, we're a toilet paper company, so what do we know about rowing? But we do know a thing or two about determination (it takes grit to make sustainable TP), and Taryn Smith's story has us absolutely hooked. This 25-year-old from landlocked Nebraska just became the first woman to cross the Atlantic alone in a 3,000-mile race—despite learning to row only after reading about someone else's achievement.
body: Let's break this down: Smith didn't grow up around water (Nebraska isn't exactly known for its oceanfront property), but something about reading about an all-female rowing team's world record sparked something in her. So she decided to learn to row. You know, as one does when living hundreds of miles from the nearest ocean.

But here's where it gets really good—Smith didn't just learn to paddle around a lake for fun. She went full send and tackled a 3,000-mile Atlantic crossing race. Alone. And not only did she complete it, she made history by becoming the first female to do it solo in this particular race.

We love everything about this story: the audacity of a Nebraskan deciding to conquer the Atlantic, the fact that she started from zero rowing experience, and most of all, that she turned reading about someone else's success into fuel for her own ocean dreams. Sometimes the best adventures start in the most unexpected places—even if that place is about as far from the ocean as you can get in America.

featured.originalTitle: Scientists discover protein that could heal leaky gut and ease depression
featured.headline: Gut Feeling: Protein Discovery Links Tummy Troubles to Mental Health
featured.excerpt: Scientists have identified a protein called Reelin that plays a key role in both gut repair and brain health. When chronic stress damages the gut's protective lining, it lowers Reelin levels, potentially worsening depression through the gut-brain connection.
featured.author: Hope Springs

fullContent.lead: Look, we're a toilet paper company, so when we say we're interested in gut health, that probably makes sense. But here's some news that goes way beyond our usual territory (though still involves your insides): scientists have discovered a protein that might be the missing link between your gut and your mood.
body: According to a report from Science Daily, researchers have identified a protein called Reelin that plays a key role in both gut repair and brain health. Think of it as your body's little maintenance crew, working overtime to keep things running smoothly in two very important places.

Here's where it gets interesting (and a bit concerning): when you're dealing with chronic stress, it actually damages your gut's protective lining. We're talking about that crucial barrier that keeps the good stuff in and the bad stuff out. When this lining takes a hit, your Reelin levels drop, which could potentially make depression worse through something called the gut-brain connection.

Now, we'll be the first to admit that as a company that makes toilet paper, our scientific commentary should probably be taken with a grain of salt. But this research hints at something pretty fascinating – that the health of your gut and the health of your mind might be more connected than we previously thought. It's like your body has its own internal internet, and sometimes the connection gets a bit glitchy when stress enters the picture.

featured.originalTitle: A field of wheat becomes the world's largest living photograph
featured.headline: Picture This: Wheat Field Grows Into World's Largest Living Photo
featured.excerpt: The Farming Photographs project is creating a photographic-style artwork by dividing a field into 'pixels' of different wheat varieties. The ambitious project aims to create the world's largest living photograph using agricultural crops.
featured.author: Adam Atom

fullContent.lead: Look, we're a toilet paper company writing about art, so maybe take our commentary with a grain of salt (pun intended). But when we heard about farmers turning a wheat field into what they're calling the world's largest living photograph, we had to share it. Because honestly, that's just brilliant.
body: The Farming Photographs project is doing something pretty extraordinary – they're creating photographic-style artwork by dividing a field into 'pixels' made of different wheat varieties. Think of it like a massive, living version of those pixel art pieces you might make in Photoshop, except instead of digital squares, each 'pixel' is an actual patch of wheat.

According to the report, this ambitious project aims to create the world's largest living photograph using agricultural crops. We're talking about turning farmland into functional art that grows, changes with the seasons, and presumably feeds people too. It's like the ultimate multitasking – feeding bodies and feeding souls at the same time.

The beauty of this project is in its simplicity and scale. Different wheat varieties naturally have different colors and textures, so by strategically planting them in patterns, farmers can essentially 'paint' with crops. It's agricultural pointillism, if you will – step back far enough, and those individual wheat pixels come together to form a larger image.

It's a refreshing reminder that sometimes the most creative solutions come from working with what you've got, rather than wishing you had something else.

climate.originalTitle: 750-year-old Indian poems reveal a landscape scientists got wrong
climate.headline: Poetry Proves Scientists Wrong About Ancient Indian Landscapes
climate.excerpt: Ancient Indian poems and folk songs dating back to the 1200s reveal that western India's savannas are natural landscapes, not degraded forests. The literary evidence closely matches today's thorny trees and grasslands, reshaping conservation understanding.
climate.author: Forrest Green

fullContent.lead: Look, we sell toilet paper, so what do we know about ancient poetry? Apparently enough to get excited about a story that proves sometimes the old ways of seeing things were right all along. Scientists have discovered that 750-year-old Indian poems and folk songs contain some pretty impressive environmental wisdom that's reshaping how we understand conservation today.
body: Here's the scoop: researchers have been poring over ancient Indian literature dating back to the 1200s, and what they found is beautifully simple. These centuries-old poems and folk songs describe western India's landscapes in vivid detail - thorny trees scattered across grasslands, exactly matching what you'd see if you visited those savannas today.

But here's where it gets interesting (and a little embarrassing for modern science). For years, scientists assumed these savannas were degraded forests - basically nature's equivalent of a fixer-upper that had seen better days. The thinking was that human activity had somehow damaged what used to be lush, dense forests, leaving behind these scrubby grasslands.

Turns out, according to the report, the poets knew better. The literary evidence reveals that these savannas aren't damaged ecosystems at all - they're natural landscapes that have looked pretty much the same for centuries. It's like finding out that the vintage look you thought was artificially distressed was actually just... vintage.

This discovery is reshaping conservation understanding in a big way. Instead of trying to 'fix' these landscapes by turning them into forests, conservationists now have solid evidence that protecting these savannas as they are might be the right approach. Sometimes the best science comes from listening to the voices that have been there all along - even if those voices happen to be singing 750-year-old songs.

body: For years, doctors have known that statin medications can cause muscle pain in some patients, but the 'why' has been frustratingly elusive. It's been one of those medical mysteries that's made both doctors and patients scratch their heads – helpful for cholesterol, rough on the muscles, but nobody could explain the connection.

Now, according to a report from Science Daily, researchers have identified the molecular trigger behind this side effect. Turns out, statins have been jamming open a critical muscle protein, which sounds about as comfortable as it sounds. This protein malfunction causes toxic calcium to leak out, and that's where the muscle pain comes from.

Here's the exciting part (and why we're filing this under 'good news'): understanding the mechanism could lead to safer drug development. When you know exactly what's going wrong, you can start figuring out how to fix it. This discovery might pave the way for cholesterol medications that don't leave people hobbling around like they overdid it at the gym.
